title: Top 5 ways to Hit For More POWER in Baseball
text:
We are going to demonstrate five ways to help players hit for more power. The first drill involves using a medicine ball to work on explosive movements and throwing power. The second drill uses different weighted balls to help players drive through the ball and make solid contact. The third drill is the walk-through drill, where players take a full swing and follow through with two steps towards the pitcher's mound. The fourth drill is the skater or step back drill, which focuses on coiling up on the backside and unloading on the ball. Finally, the fifth drill involves sitting on a bucket to help players maintain good posture and feel their backside stay down in their legs during their swing. These drills aim to improve a player's hitting power by building strength, improving technique, and maintaining good posture.

title: TOP 5 ways to hit pitchers who throw GAS
text:
Coach Duke and Coach Steve demonstrate the top 5 ways to train against pitchers who throw gas. All right coaches, those are our top five drills to help your players hit faster pitching. Remember, the key to success is repetition and challenging your players in practice so that they are prepared for game time. It's also important to maintain a good tempo and stay tight and compact in their swings. By using these drills, you'll be able to help your players hit those fast pitchers with confidence. Happy coaching!
 -
1.  Three Plate Drill: Using three home plates set up at different distances to simulate a pitcher throwing at different speeds. The closer the plate, the faster the ball will get on the hitter.
2.  Ball Drop Drill: Holding a baseball or a mush ball as high as possible, then dropping it and hitting it, to help the player's reaction time and speed up their swing.
3.  Three Ball Quick Toss: Quickly presenting three baseballs for the hitter to hit, in order to stay tight and compact in their swing.
4.  Hack Attack Pitching Machine: Using a machine to challenge the player and get them used to seeing different velocities, to help them prepare for game time.
5.  Close Overhand Batting Practice: Throwing batting practice from a closer distance to challenge the player's reaction time and help them hit faster pitches.

title: Adjust to Slow Pitching IMMEDIATELY (Pro Tip)
location: Baseball Hitting Drills & Pro Tips
text:
Coach Steve explains how to adjust to different pitches. He said he visualizes driving the ball into the opposite side of the field gap to ensure successful and powerful contact.

Then he brings us into his three plate drill. The plates are arranged going toward the coach doing the front toss. The drill focuses on time and rhythm to avoid being rushed or beginning the swing too early. The plate farthest from the coach simulates a slow pitch/change up, the middle plate simulates an average pitcher, while the closest plate simulates a pitcher that throws very hard. Meanwhile, the coach throws the ball at the exact same speed, using the distance to create the differences in the drill.

The player's goal is to stay at the same pace and rhythm no matter what plate they are swinging at. They should adjust to the different pitches by changing what time they begin their load, whether it is during when the pitcher first starts moving or while the ball is on its way toward the plate, the adjustments avoid rushing or being too early.

title: Managing Your Assistant Coaches | YOUTH BASEBALL
location: How to Coach Your Team Pro Tips & Hacks
text:
One quality that every great coaching staff is their ability to divide and conquer at practice and in games.  Too often, youth coaches all yell and scream out instructions & directions from the dugout.  This can be confusing for players because each coach might be yelling out something different!

Sit down with your coaching staff and go over each coaches job during practice & at games.  It can be challenging to monitor the whole game all at once.  For example, you can have one coach managing the pitch calling, another coach working with infielders, one coach working with the hitters/offense, and the last coach working with the outfielders/positioning and where they should be playing.  This gives each coach a specific responsibility during the games and one thing to focus on.

Remember, we're not playing a video game!  We can't just yell and scream out where the ball needs to go.  Teach in practice and let your players learn from failure in the game!

title: Situational Play | Build Baseball IQ
location: How to Coach Your Team Pro Tips & Hacks
text:
Baseball & Softball IQ are things that come from experience and playing time.  Here at Dominate the Diamond, we created Baseball IQ cards to teach the players on our team certain situations and what to do in them.

We can never assume that our players will understand situations, defensive assignments, situational hitting, reading the pace of the ball, knowing the speed of the runner etc... title: PERFECT TECHNIQUE for Tag Plays at Home Plate
location: Catching Drills & Pro Tips
text:
Coach Brandon Martorano is a prospect catcher in the SF Giants organization and he shares a great drill he performs to practice tag plays at home plate.

When the catcher sets up to make a tag out at home plate, the positioning will vary depending on where the ball is hit.  Make sure that the mask stays on when we make the tag out.  We should position our heels on the front corner of the plate for a straight away throw from CF.  Try to get a good read on the throw, read the hops, the angle and get your chest lined up to the throw.

As a catcher, we have to let the runner have a "sliding lane" before the ball is in our glove.  Once the ball is in our glove, we can then position our body to block home plate.  After we catch the ball, we want to lean and drive to the left  towards the runner sliding into the plate.  Remember to hold the ball in our bare hand in the glove.  At times, we may have to use a 1 hand swipe tag technique but at the younger ages we prefer to use 2 hands.  Once we apply the tag, sell it to the umpire and get ready for the next play with less than 2 outs!

title: How Close Should The Catcher Be to the Batter?
location: Catching Drills & Pro Tips
text:

The proper set up for the catcher behind home plate is to have a batter stand in the batters box in practice.  The catcher should be able to reach out and touch the batters back knee. If the catcher is too far back, we will be receiving the ball too deep and make strikes look like balls down in the zone.  Have your catchers work on this in practice so they have the confidence to set up correctly in the game.

title: Don't Be Afraid of the Ball (HIT BY PITCH)
location: Baseball Hitting Drills & Pro Tips
text:
Coaches Duke Baxter and Steve Nikorak shares their personal experiences getting hit by pitches and how to confidently teach youth players how to overcome the fear of getting hit.

Getting hit by the ball and being afraid to hit is something that all youth baseball and softball players go through.  There are a few simple steps to take when trying to build confidence or re assure your players that getting hit by the ball is part of the game!

1.  Teach your players how to get hit correctly!
       a. Turn in & Tuck the Chin
       b. Drop the Barrel
       c. This allows them to get hit in the meaty parts of their body where it doesn't hurt as    bad.

2. Mix in balls during front toss or BP to show them that they have time to get hit if the ball is thrown at them.
      a. Use tennis balls, smush ball, or incredi-balls to hit them in their back side.
      b.  This will give them the confidence to get out of the way on time.

3. Try to get the message through to them that getting hit is part of the game!  It may only happen a handful of times all season.  We don't want to waste hundred's of at bats worried about something that may only happen 1, 2, 3 times a year.

A typical drill used in practices and before games is the highly used Soft Toss or Side Toss.

This drill is great to help warm up your players and to get their bodies ready for batting practice.

Here is how you Side Toss.
1. Present the ball to the hitter by showing it to them so they get ready.
2. Bring the hand back slow and keep the tempo the same throughout the toss.
3. When you toss the ball aim for the front pocket or belt area of the hitter.
4. You can mix up the locations but stay smooth and toss the ball in front of the hitter.
Always remember to take your time as the tosser so that the hitter can get ready and repeat the movement.

title: 3 great drills for teaching kids how to catch fly balls | Youth baseball fielding drills
location: The Best Infield Drills & Pro Tips
text:
We often get asked, what's the best way to help youth baseball players learn to catch fly balls in the infield or outfield.  We have 3 great drills that the players love and really help them to judge fly balls and learn to catch them while having a great time.

The first is the flyball competition drill.  This can be done inside or outside.  Have players toss their baseball in the air and the first one to catch 5 (or 10) flyballs wins.  It sounds simple but especially with the young kids, they'll be throwing them all over the place and have to run for them and judge where they'll land.  Use squishy balls with the younger kids.

The second drill for practicing catching fly balls is the zig zag drill.  Set up cones in a zig zag pattern on the field.  Then have a coach throw to the player and have them use their prep step in  zig zag motion as their catching the fly ball.

The third drill that the kids love is the Squishy Fly Ball Drill.  Using a squishy ball throw a fly ball and have the kids "catch it" with the rim of their hat.  This requires them to position themselves under the ball.  They have a blast and it helps them learn how to judge where the ball will land.

title: How to Teach the Do or Die Play in Baseball
text:
#baseball #throwing
In this fast paced video, Steve Nikorak demonstrates a drill for throwing on the run and working on making your players comfortable with uncomfortable throws. With only 2 cones, the players can gather the necessary skills for accuracy toward first base at any speed or positioning. The baseball players sprint through the cones, simulate fielding the ball, transfer weight onto the right leg, and throw at any body angle, as would happen in the real game.
